title: How to Make Oreo Hot Chocolate

steps.headline: Heat 3 cups (700 milliliters) of milk until it just begins to steam.
steps.description: Pour 3 cups (700 milliliters) of whole milk into a saucepan. Cook the milk over medium-low heat, whisking occasionally, until it just begins to steam. This will take about 8 to 10 minutes. While you're waiting for the milk to heat up, get started on the next step.

steps.headline: Blend the remaining milk, condensed milk, Oreos, and cocoa powder.
steps.description: Pour the remaining 1 cup (240 milliliters) of milk into a blender. Add the sweetened condensed milk, Oreos, and unsweetened cocoa powder. Close the blender, and blend on high until smooth, about 2 minutes. You can use a food processor as well, but it would be a good idea to cover the lid with a towel to prevent leaks. For creamier hot chocolate, add 1 tablespoon (7.5 grams) of cornstarch or cornflour to the blender.

steps.headline: Add the Oreo mixture to the saucepan.
steps.description: Pour the blended Oreo mixture into the saucepan. Stir everything together with a whisk until the color is consistent.

steps.headline: Cook the mixture over medium-low heat for another 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Whisk the mixture often and do not let it come to a boil. It is ready when the Oreo mixture is completely dissolved and mixed into the milk.

steps.headline: Divide the hot chocolate between 4 mugs.
steps.description: Alternatively, you can divide it between 2 large mugs, and have larger serving sizes instead. To avoid spills and wasting any hot chocolate, use a soup ladle to transfer it from the saucepan to the mugs. You can pour it straight from the saucepan if you are careful, however.

steps.headline: Garnish and serve the hot chocolate.
steps.description: Add a dollop of whipped cream on top of the hot chocolate, then sprinkle it with crushed Oreos. You can leave the hot chocolate ungarnished and serve it as-is.

steps.headline: Heat the milk over medium-low heat until it just begins to simmer.
steps.description: Pour 2 cups (470 milliliters) of whole milk into a saucepan. Turn the heat up to medium-low, and allow the milk to cook until it just begins to simmer. Stir the milk often with a whisk, and do not let it come to a boil. For richer hot chocolate, try 1 cup (240 milliliters) of whole milk and 1 cup (240 milliliters) of heavy cream.

steps.headline: Remove the saucepan from heat and whisk in the hot chocolate powder.
steps.description: If you can't find hot chocolate powder, use ¼ cup (25 grams) of unsweetened cocoa powder and ¼ cup (55 grams) of granulated white sugar. Don't use unsweetened cocoa powder on its own, or the hot chocolate won't be sweet enough. Try "candy cane" hot chocolate powder for a minty cookies n' flavor.

steps.headline: Grind the Oreos, then add them to the hot chocolate.
steps.description: You can do this using a blender or food processor. Make sure that you grind the Oreos into a fine powder. If there are any large chunks, they won't dissolve properly, and you'll get a gritty, grainy hot chocolate instead.

steps.headline: Whisk the hot chocolate until everything is dissolved.
steps.description: This should only take a few minutes. You need both the hot chocolate powder and the crushed Oreos to be completely mixed. The color should be even and the texture should be consistent.

steps.headline: Divide the hot chocolate between 2 mugs, then serve it.
steps.description: For a fancier treat, garnish the hot chocolate with a swirl of whipped cream. Add a sprinkle of crushed Oreos on top. You can leave the hot chocolate plain, without any whipped cream or Oreos.
